title: Nadiya Hussain's son has some brutal home truths about her new book
text:
You can trust your kids to be honest (Picture: BBC)

Nadiya Hussain may be a bestselling author, but the baker admitted that she has no harsher critics than her own children when it comes to her writing.

The Great British Bake Off winner appeared on Friday night’s episode of The Graham Norton Show to celebrate the launch of her new book Finding My Voice, where she confessed that her son was keeping her grounded when it came to her success.

‘After he’d read some of it he said: “I like the book, but there are better writers,”’ the mum-of-three laughed.

Kids: you can always trust them to be honest.

The 34-year-old TV personality sat on Graham Norton’s infamous red sofa alongside Debbie Harry, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Linda Hamilton (what a lineup!), where she spoke about the importance of being a role model for young Muslim women.

‘If you’d asked me four years ago I would have said that I just wanted to cook and write and being Muslim was incidental,’ she said, ‘but now I see how important the role is that I have.’

Nadiya’s book is available to buy now (Picture: Ken McKay/ITV/REX)

Well said, Nadiya.

Her first foray into telling her life story, Finding My Voice sees Nadiya discuss life with mental health issues as someone who suffers from panic attacks.

One shocking revelation to come from Nadiya’s memoir was the story that the TV personality was sexually abused by a family friend as a child, admitting that she had attempted to take her own life because of the incident and believed it had ‘played a role’ in her panic disorder.

Appearing on Lorraine on Thursday, the star opened up about seeing her past trauma play out in the press, saying: ‘It’s frightening.’

She continued: ‘I’m not gonna lie there were moments where you read these headlines and what I wanted to do was take the book back and hide in a cave.’

Nadiya said her memoir was for ’14-year-old me’ and also dedicated it to people ‘who are finding their voice and who feel like they are not represented.’

‘I feel like if I didn’t write this book and I didn’t write these stories, I’d be part of a bigger problem not a solution and I think it’s very important to speak.’
